text: Air traffic in a couple key spots in this country is congested,

label: n
text: in part, because airlines are flying more smaller planes rather than fewer larger planes - to carry the same amount of passengers.

label: n
text: This takes up more landing slots.

label: n
text: 1 Planes are charged landing fees based on weight,

label: n
text: and therefore it can be cheaper to land 2 smaller, lighter planes rather than one larger, heavier plane.

label: n
text: 2 Airlines are worried that if they swap out 2 lighter planes for 1 heavier plane, then another airline will come in and take the landing slot and offer an extra flight of its own and siphon off passengers.

label: n
text: Airlines worry that if they don't offer the most frequent flights, packed especially into the most desired times for business travelers, their competition will.

label: u
text: This leads to an inefficient bunching of many flights on somewhat smaller planes at peak times, leading to congestion and delays.

label: u
text: The government should change the basis on which landing fees are calculated as a start toward dis-incentivizing these practices.

label: u
text: 1 The landing fees should not be based primarily on weight, but rather should be based on the fact that the plane is using a landing slot, with only some consideration given to the weight of the aircraft.

label: u
text: That would encourage airlines to choose larger planes that can carry more people with less per-person environmental impact and fewer overall landing slots, reducing delays.

label: u
text: 2 The landing fees should be somewhat greater at peak times of day to encourage airlines to spread out their flights more, thereby reducing congestion and delays.
